# Shore Terminology

## Preface

This document intent is to provide a high-level overview of the terms scattered in the `Shore` project.
What to keep in mind while reading this doc:

1. Shore is a `project` based software.
2. Shore is built to be extensible.
3. Shore is a framework.

Each of the following terms is represented by an entity in the system.

When viewing code, it is recommended to search for these terms to see the interface or/and implementation of these interfaces.

## Highlevel

[![](https://mermaid.-)](https://mermaid-js.github.io/mermaid-live-editor/#-)

## Project

A `shore project` is the set of files and directories the `shore-cli` depends on.

These files may vary between `backend` and/or `renderer` implementations but the building blocks are the same.

At the time of writing, a standard `shore` project follows this pattern:

```bash
my-awesome-pipeline/
├── .gitignore
├── main.pipeline.jsonnet
├── go.mod
├── go.sum
├── require.go
├── render.yaml
├── exec.yaml
|── E2E.yaml
└── vendor/
    └── modules.txt
```

The `project` handles the common files that are expected to be used such as `render.yaml`, `exec.yaml`, `E2E.yaml`, `require.go` and will validate their existence when invoking a command.

A common interaction between a `project` & another entity is passing the file's contents to the entity, this is discussed in further detail for each entity.

## Renderer

A Renderer is an abstraction layer which wraps a templating language in order to process the project inputs.

A rendering engine takes in code (input), processes the data and outputs the rendered format (currently JSON) for further processing by another system, such as `HCL`, `Jsonnet`, `CUElang` and others.

Currently only `Jsonnet` is supported.

The `shore-cli` will coordinate between the `project` & a `renderer` to pass in additional files that aren't supported by default. Mainly `render.yaml` and shared libraries if they are not supported natively by the templating language.

Shared libraries are snippets of code hosted in Github that can be pulled to the local machine. The code snippets are used to encapsulate logic in a different location that isn't the main code base.

Interface: `Render` (`Test` may be implemented in the future)

## Backend

The `backend` is an abstraction layer of a generic `pipeline` backend such as `Spinnaker`, `Tekton`, `ArgoCD`, etc..

A backend should implement the high level concepts of working with pipelines. These concepts are encapsulated by the interface definition.

The Pipeline in a context of a backend is an automated stored procedure that could be invoked that will carry out process on a remote server (in the Cloud, on someone else's computer!).

Examples of pipelines are: Spinnaker Pipelines, Jenkins Jobs, Tekton Jobs, AWS StepFunctions.

Currently only `Spinnaker` is listed as a supported backend.

Interface: `Save (Create or Update)`, `Execute`, `TestRemote`

### JSONNET - Shared libraries

To support common use-cases and features, the JSONNET renderer that is shipped with `shore-cli` provides a mechanism for `shared-library` loading.

Sharing code via a libraries allows for easier to maintain code and better separation of concerns. As JSONNET does not implement this feature, `shore-cli` provides it via the `JSONNET` renderer.
